concept.title: generate.copy.outer parameter
concept.shortdesc: Elaboration on how the generate.copy.outer parameter functions.

section.title: Background
section.p:
This is an issue in the following situations:
The DITA map is in a directory that is a peer to directories that contain referenced objects.
The DITA map is in a directory that is below the directories that contain the referenced objects.

Let's assume that the directory structure for the DITA content looks like the following:images/ fig.png maps/ start.ditamap topics/ topic.ditaThe DITA map is in the maps directory, the topics are in the topics directory, and the images are in the images directory.

section.title: Setting the generate.copy.outer parameter to 1
section.p: Let's assume that you run the HTML5 transformation. By default, The DITA-OT uses the generate.copy.outer parameter with a value of 1. Output is not built for the topics. You receive only the following output: index.html commonltr.css commonrtl.cssThe index.html file contains the navigation structure, but all the links are broken, since no HTML5 files were built for the topics.
How do you fix this? By specifying a value of 3 for the generate.copy.outer parameter.

section.title: Setting the generate.copy.outer parameter to 3
section.p: Now your output directory structure looks like this: images/ fig.png maps/ index.html topics/ topic.html commonltr.css commonrtl.cssThe index.html file is in the maps directory, and the CSS and other files are located in the output directory. Copying the output directory is simplified.
